title: Women in the United States House of Representatives
summary: Women have served in the United States House of Representatives since the 1917 entrance of Jeannette Rankin from Montana, a Republican. In total, 348 women have been U.S. representatives and seven more women have been non-voting delegates. As of November 4, 2021, there are 120 women in the U.S. House of Representatives (not counting four female non-voting delegates), making women 27.6% of the total.[1] Of the 355 women who have served in the House, 233 have been Democrats (including four from U.S. territories or the District of Columbia) and 122 have been Republicans (including three from U.S. territories, including pre-statehood Hawaii). One woman has been Speaker of the House, Democrat Nancy Pelosi of California.
